PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual is asked to answer it in exactly the same way. Some may provide five or ten answers; others may give only one or two. To make matters worse, there are many questions which are not applicable to everyone. Therefore, it is best to answer the questions as they appear, if they apply to you.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada between 1924 and 1954, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? WM. DAY - FARMER

6. When did you come to Saskatoon? (Give month and year): MAY, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible:

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.) 21

9. What were your reasons for coming West? MOSTLY THE SPIRIT OF ADVENTURE

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through people & Govt. information
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought I was nuts.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I was a lone wolf.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I rode the plats, eating out of a nose bag. This term covers eating out a lunch box.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Remember, it was a long, tiresome trip, especially through the mud around the lakes. I also remember the different types of immigrants. Polish, Russian, Dagos etc. Very few British.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I landed in Wolseley. (Another crew landed near me. I couldn't sleep for the noise. Bull frogs singing their song.)

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

NE 30 Township 17 Range 14

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

WOODROW and GLENTYVORTH

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

1. Store clerk
2. Store clerk in Montreal
3. Later, farm hand, railroading
4. Surveying well digging etc etc
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I used the plains, eating out at a Rose Hotel. She turned some coloring out.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents, excitement, etc.)

Remember, there's a long journey ahead.

Especially the trip, especially the trip, especially the trip.

I started my work in a small town.

16. Where did you settle or take up residence in Saskatchewan?

NE 30, Township 3, Range 17.

17. Mention any other places they have lived.

WOODROW

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

STORE CLERK, STORE CLERK, RAILROADING, LATER FARM, HANG WELL DIGGING, SURVEYING, etc., etc.

LONGER WHEN I STARTED ON HOMESTEAD

WIFE L. WILSON '1917' WINNIPEG

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

YES When I became established,
I make a home for my parents
on the farm.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

A sister also came also two
brothers. One brother left to fight
in War 1914-1918.
The other studied for the church
of the ordained at Edmonton.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

I was on a Sunday party, and was lost for
3 days, coming to dense fog. Our horses were
on picket-lines & some antelope scared
them, and away they bolted, we tried in
vain to catch them. Then the fog made it
impossible for me to follow them. After myself
on the banks of Wood River, where the town
of Gravelbourg now stands.
Later the train was moved & moved the
harness.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

I have covered hundreds of miles from
Weyburn to Swift Current.
From the state of Montana to the
Slave Lake, also to the coast.
Both horse back & train.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1926

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Worpsaw 20 miles, Siletzworth 14 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   At the first homestead days once in 6 months.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   When our train came to Siletzworth we got our mail Friday or Sat morning.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Long about 1920. About 20% through mail order catalogues.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1920. Built by Swan Valley Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   After I acquired a homestead I started to farm for myself. Since I had to stay to pay off the mortgage.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Most of the settlers stayed for the same reason I did.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Quite a number moved away during the drought. Not many came back. I stayed and lived on the property of a little brother for $8 per month for a family of 3 persons.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a school secretary at various times, also councillor for 14 years. Also active in the formation of the local wheat pool etc., etc.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Organized the first grain growers lodge at Lorn Valley school & promoted the first church service to be held in the community. My wife was the organizer until we retired from farm life in 1948.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Speaking of my farm life. The introduction of mechanical machines for large scale operations really spoiled the romance of pioneer life. The single farmer could not compete with his larger scale farmers. Would family find a slow death.
